lines.text: I know it's terrible trying to have any faith when people are doing such horrible... But you know what I sometimes think? I think the world may be going through a phase, the way I was with mother. It'll pass. Maybe not hundreds of years, but someday. - I still believe, in spite of everything, that people are really good at heart.
We don't need the Nazis to destroy us. We're destroying ourselves.
Always remember this Anna, there are no walls, no bolts, no locks that anyone can put on your mind.
[last lines]

[voiceover]
In spite of everything, I still believe that people are really good at heart.

[spoken]
She puts me to shame.
For the past two years we have lived in fear. Now we can live in hope.
You know we're going to forget how to dance.
You know the most wonderful part of thinking yourself outside. You can have it any way you like. You can have rows of roses and violets all blooming in the same season, isn't that wonderful!
You know what I do when I think I can't stand another minute cooped up? I think myself outside.
[Reading the note Anne included with her crossword book]
You have never lost your temper / You never will, I fear / You are so good / But if you should / Put all your cross words here.

[to Mr. Dussel]
No, it's not like Saint Nicholas Day! What kind of Jew are you that you don't know Hanukkah?
Our blessed radio. It gives us eyes and ears out into the world. We listen to the German station only for good music. And we listen to the BBC for hope.
Sometimes I wish the end would come, whenever.
Margot!
At least we'd know where we were.
You should be ashamed of yourself, talking that way. Think how lucky we are, think of the thousands dying in the war every day, think of the people in concentration camps.
What's the good of that? What's the good of thinking of misery when you're already miserable?
Stop it! Let's be happy.
Already I know what I want to do, don't you. I want to be a journalist or something. I love to write.
I want to go on living even after I'm dead.
We're not the only people that have had to suffer, there have always been people that've had to.
You're spoiling the whole invasion!
I've never heard grownups quarrel before
It's not a quarrel, it's a discussion. And I've never heard children so rude before.
[first lines]
Mr. Frank. - Mr Frank?
Kraler. - Mr. Kraler. Miep. My good friends.

[chuckling, relieved]
Es ist eine Katze!
[It's a cat!]

[laughs]
Ja.
[Yes]

[calls the cat in German]
Miez, Miez, Miez! Miez, Mieez!
[Kitty...!]

[Peter has removed the Star of David badge from his coat]
You took off your star.
That's right.
You can't do that. They arrest you if you go out without your star.
Who's going out?
What are you going to do with it?
Burn it.
I don't think I could burn mine. I don't know why.
You couldn't? Something they made you wear so they could kick you around?
I know, but after all, it is the Star of David, isn't it?

[to Anne]
Being here has certain advantages for you. Now for instance, you remember that battle you had with your mother the other day on the subject of overshoes? You said you would rather die than wear overshoes, remember? And what happened? In the end you had to wear them. Now, you see, for as long as we are here, you won't have to wear overshoes, isn't that great? And the piano. You won't have to practice on the piano. I tell you, this is going to be a fine life for you.
how good Margot is.
I want to bring out all kinds of things that lie buried deep in my heart.
We try and hold on to some kind of ideals, when everything - ideals, hope, everything is being destroyed.
Let me see your tongue.
[opens her mouth]

[opens his door]
Quack.
